Posts.Content: You should have an ultrasound and see if it is indeed a solid nodule. If it is solid, a biopsy should be performed.
Posts.Title: My Mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Lintek, Thank you for your response. You definately have a family history don't you? I'm sure you are very diligent with check-ups because of this. I am 43 and do still have cycles. This area that the doctor tried to aspirate has been there for five years and does go up and down in size. The day I went, it was smaller in size (ping pong ball size) but definately palpable. If it was small I would think that he just missed it, but if he missed something that size I don't think I want him operating on me, LOL! If the fluid went away in the cyst, the lump would just go away, right? I guess there is no reason to drive myself crazy guessing what happened. I will go for the new ultrasound Friday and see what it shows. I have a follow-up with the surgeon the Thursday after that.
Posts.Title: Anyone ever heard of a breast cyst with no fluid inside to aspirate?

Posts.Content: I have some breast cysts that I have had for about five years. I have had numerous mammograms and ultrasounds throughout this five years for these cysts and other things breast related. These cysts are in the same area and have grown quite large, sometimes getting to the size of an egg, and then shrinking back down to the size of a pingpong ball. I have never been concerned with these cysts because they have been proven as cysts and not solid via ultrasound. So, I went to a surgeon today about another breast lump to get a second opinion on a biopsy and he felt this grouping of cysts and said he wanted to do a fine needle aspiration. I had never had that before on these cysts. Well, to my surprise and his, no fluid was present! He didn't get a drop of anything and tried several times. I have seen these cysts myself on the ultrasound screen and I have all the reports from the ultrasounds and mammograms and I know these are not solid masses. Has anyone ever heard of breast cysts with no fluid?
Posts.Title: Anyone ever heard of a breast cyst with no fluid inside to aspirate?

Posts.Content: Hi Linda, To answer some of your questions, I will not be hearing from the ultrasound until I go for the follow-up with the doctor next week. He had me go to the radiologist's office and pick up every mammo. and ultrasound I have ever had done, which was ALOT! He wants his radiologist to look over everything I've ever had done from the beginning plus have another ultrasound. I was going to this surgeon for a second opinion on the suggestion of a new doctor I have been going to who felt all this stuff in my breasts should be taken out surgically. She read my biopsy report from the lump in the other breast and became concerned. I had a core needle biopsy in the other breast 2 years ago and it showed I had either a fibroadenoma or a phyllodes tumor. The pathology report said it showed signs of being a benign phyllodes tumor. It is 2.2 cm. This new doctor said this needs to come out as all phyllodes tumors need to be removed and with margins. Everything I have read about these tumors correlates with what she says. The problem is I live in a very small town and these doctors don't know much about phyllodes. The first surgeon I went to said he had seen one in his career as a doctor and he is around 60 years old. So, I think the time has come to just have all this stuff surgically removed. I have been x-rayed and ultrasounded ad nauseum over the last 5 years and I'm tired of worrying about it all. I just want it gone! Tell me about your 2 cm. lump. You are going for an ultrasound tomorrow? When will you find out what it says? I know with your family history you must worry when anything is found.
Posts.Title: Anyone ever heard of a breast cyst with no fluid inside to aspirate?

Posts.Content: Hi Andrew, Any new lump, whether it is painful or not, should be evaluated by a doctor. Give it a couple of weeks and if it doesn't go away, go have it checked out. A lump anywhere that doesn't go away should be checked out.
Posts.Title: Weird lump in chest

Posts.Content: It could be an infection, a cyst, or a plugged milk duct. There is also a tumor called a phyllodes tumor that can appear literally overnight and already be big when you find it. They can be painful or not painful and can be anywhere from benign to cancerous. I have one and it literally was just there one day and it is 2.2 cm. She is definately doing the right thing by getting that ultrasound. Please come back and let us know what the ultrasound shows.
Posts.Title: large breast lunp

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by SunshineinCA She wasn't sure that my Mother's colon cancer (My Mom was dx at 48) could increase my risk of BC - she wasn't sure if it colon cancer is linked or not to BC and not sure if that is why my Sister had an increased risk - OK she's the Surgeon - if she doesn't know then who does?? If you have a family member with colon cancer, that increases your risk for colon cancer. A person with colon cancer has an increased risk of having breast cancer. So I would think it does increase your chances for breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: If the ultrasound showed a cyst, which would be hollow on the inside, then yes they could say it is a benign lump. HOWEVER, if the lump is solid, there is no way possible to tell you for certain it is benign without a biopsy. If it is solid it can have characteristics which look more benign or cancerous, but there is no way to say it is "this or that" for certain without a biopsy. Can you call them back and ask exactly what the ultrasound showed? If they say a cyst, that's great! If they say a solid lesion, you need more follow-up.
Posts.Title: Diagnosing a lump as benign w/o a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Be sure when you go for your exam that you tell the doctor that it has grown. There is breast tissue that is unable to be reached with a mammogram, but not sure if this is the case with you. Insist on getting it checked out with an ultrasound. They are painless and very cost efficient.
Posts.Title: Pea sized lump in breast

Posts.Content: It is according to what type of lump you are referring to. If it is a cyst, then it can stay where it is. There are certain tumors that need to come out even though they are not cancer because they can grow quite large in a short period of time. Do you know what type of lump it is? Did she have a biopsy or an ultrasound?
Posts.Title: What is the treatment of having a lump in the breast of a 17 year old girl?

Posts.Content: Cystic lesion is probably a fluid filled cyst. The solid lesion needs to be biopsied. A biopsy is the only true way to tell if a solid lesion is cancerous or not, even though they can look suspicious by having uneven borders and such on the ultrasound. I think by them adding the word "homogenous" they are saying the borders are even and that's good. With your solid lesion actively growing, a biopsy would be the best thing to do. Are they suggesting a biopsy?
Posts.Title: has anyone ever heard of this before

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by JewelryJulie I forgot the word they used but essentially it is a benign tumor. Was it a fibroadenoma? There is one type of breast tumor that even though it is benign it still has to be removed surgically. It is called a phyllodes tumor.
Posts.Title: Another lump and scared

Posts.Content: I'm so glad you are okay. With the history of breast cancer in your family I know you were terrified. That call back really makes your mind run away doesn't it?
Posts.Title: Call Back for a Second Mammogram

Posts.Content: What kind of benign lump did they tell you it was?
Posts.Title: Another lump and scared

Posts.Content: Good news, indeed! Thanks for giving us an update.
Posts.Title: Another lump and scared

Posts.Content: It is a spring action needle that is hollowed out in the middle. Since the needle is cored out in the middle, when it is put into the area, it takes a piece of tissue out instead of just extracting fluid like a regular needle would be used for.
Posts.Title: core biopsy?

Posts.Content: Hi alexioda, I am 43 years old and have had many, many mammograms and ultrasounds of the breast. I want to tell you that the ultrasound is more painful to me than the mammogram! I have very sore, lumpy breasts and it is just not that bad. Here is what I would suggest you do though. Schedule your mammo for the time in your cycle that you aren't sore. This will be the best thing to ensure no discomfort. Tell the technician this is your first one and you're nervous. Remember that it takes seconds to do. They snap the picture and then hit a button to release. I was really nervous my first one, but for no reason. You will do fine.
Posts.Title: First mammogram/what to expect?

Posts.Content: Ultrasounds are usually just to zero in on certain lumps or cysts. Mammograms are still needed to get a picture of your whole breast even though you already had an ultrasound of the lumps.
Posts.Title: Mammogram after Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: With your history and to give you peace of mind, go have the specialist check it out. You do have breast tissue on your chest, under your arms, below your breasts on your ribs. It's probably nothing what you are feeling, but anytime you feel a lump you should have it checked out. Have you checked the other side to see if you feel anything similar on the other side?
Posts.Title: Lump in chest above breast

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by MariaBB That's interesting that a mamo is more detailed than an ultrasound, I didn't know that. Well since my mamo's came up clean I guess I won't worry too much. I thought I'd benefit from an ultrasound, thinking it was the more detailed test of the two. I would look at it this way, a mammo and an ultrasound are BOTH useful for different reasons and more detailed in their own way. If a lump shows up on a mammo, the mammo will not show if it is solid or cystic but an ultrasound will. On the other hand, an ultrasound will not show up calcifications (which can't be felt) but a mammo will. So, they should be used in conjunction with one another depending on the circumstances. If a lump is felt or shows up on a mammo, then an ultrasound is always warranted in that situation. If you have an inverted nipple that a mammo doesn't show up anything, I see no reason to NOT follow up with an ultrasound to see if that shows up anything. In my opinion, if your mammo didn't show up anything and you are having unusual symptoms (inverted nipple), you should follow up with an ultrasound.
Posts.Title: inverted nipple

Posts.Content: Why on a breast cancer discussion board does it edit out mam*o, or [emailÂ protected]?
Posts.Title: inverted nipple

Posts.Content: I wouldn't be overly concerned and if it hasn't grown in all that time, it probably is a fibroadenoma. I just know that when I found a lump that was solid, it had smooth edges and was round and the doctor said the only way to know for sure what a solid lesion is, is to do a biopsy. Mine turned out to be a possible phyllodes tumor but was still inconclusive even with the biopsy. I would definately go for all my follow-ups and keep an eye on it and if it starts to grow maybe think about a biopsy then.
Posts.Title: Fibro-adenoma. does this sound right?

Posts.Content: You had a doctor's order in hand for a mammogram and took it to the radiologist department and they refused to honor the doctor's order? That is not their decision to make. If there is a doctor's order they have to do what it says. Take the order back and give it to them and if they refuse have them call the doctor's office. That will straighten it all out. They cannot refuse to give you the mammogram if you have an order from the doctor.
Posts.Title: Lesion on Left Breast

Posts.Content: How does the doctor know it is a fibroadenoma? There is no way to tell for sure what a solid lump is without a biopsy. Did you have a biopsy?
Posts.Title: Fibro-adenoma. does this sound right?

Posts.Content: If you feel a new lump, it should be brought to the attention of your doctor. Any new lump should be investigated.
Posts.Title: Have Other Women Experienced This With Lumps in the Breast?

Posts.Content: I think she and the radiologist are doing the right thing. Cysts are usually not anything to worry about, but since it is complex they are being safe and checking it out. I wouldn't worry too much about the language on the report. They have common terms and language they have to use for insurance purposes and such. Keep us posted and let us know how the biopsy turns out.
Posts.Title: BI-RADS 4 --- Complex Cyst w/ slightly irregular margins?

Posts.Content: Any solid tumor needs to be biopsied whether it has asymmetry or not. Asymmetry means it has some sort of irregular border, bigger on one side or the other. Two years ago I had a solid tumor show up on mammo. and it was recommended I have a core needle biopsy. The pathology came back either a fibroadenoma or phyllodes tumor. So even the biopsies sometimes are not 100% sure, so there is no way a mammo. can be sure what a solid tumor is without a biopsy.
Posts.Title: abnormal screening/asymmetry
